The S&P 500 committee’s discretionary choices send strong market signals not only to passive and active investors but also to potential corporate entrants about what business models, sector exposures, and financial characteristics are being rewarded at the highest market echelons. Understanding the 'signaling' behind committee actions, sector balance, and investor preference is key in this prediction.

Accounting (FinancialStatementAnalysis).reasoning_for_revised_probability: After the group deliberation, I see a strong consensus among experienced forecasters—spanning index mechanics, accounting, and market structure—that ARES remains a top candidate for S&P 500 inclusion before 2026. Most peer probabilities cluster in the mid-60s-to-low-70s, all reasoning from strong sectoral need, clear technical eligibility, and persistent analyst attention. The key points giving more comfort in a modest upward revision are: (1) repeated identification of ARES as 'next up' for a financial slot, (2) multiple expert corrections reminding that index additions can occur off-cycle if a vacancy arises, and (3) agreement that the committee's unpredictability does impose real limits, but the historical base rate for a candidate of this profile is higher than I initially weighted. My main concern—committee discretion—persists, but is somewhat outweighed by the clear structural drivers and the frequency with which large, boring financials eventually make it. Several group critiques argued that a probability in the lower 60s somewhat underweights the scenario base rate for candidates like ARES, particularly as we approach year-end and with sector rebalancing pressure. Therefore, I am raising my probability, but remain below the more aggressive mid-to-high 70s/80s forecasts due to ongoing uncertainty as seen with recent snubs (e.g., MSTR, Robinhood).

Accounting (EarningsQualityAssessment).reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing group deliberation, I note a consistent cluster of well-supported forecasts placing the probability in the 65-75% range. Multiple forecasters provided persuasive arguments regarding the risks posed by committee discretion, the possibility of continued preference for tech/fintech, and the sharply diminished odds post-major annual rebalance absent a clear near-term index vacancy. While ARES's accounting quality and sector fit are exceptional, several credible peers (including IndexProcess, Fundamental, MarketMicrostructure, and SignalingTheory experts) highlighted that the mere existence of one or two high-quality windows before year-end, combined with a crowded queue and lingering randomness, makes a forecast above ~75% difficult to sustain. Strong base rates for eligible financials remain, but I recognize I underweighted the possibility of sudden new, highly compelling candidates or a fintech/tech 'run' to year-end. My adjustment reflects this committee unpredictability and the practical likelihood that at most 1-2 additional slots will open before 2026.

question_details.title: Will the following companies be added to the S&P 500 before 2026? (ARES)
question_details.description:
The [S\&P 500 Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%26P_500) is a stock market index that measures the stock performance of 500 large companies listed on stock exchanges in the United States. The index is maintained by [S\&P Dow Jones Indices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%26P_Dow_Jones_Indices), and inclusion decisions are based on factors such as market capitalization, liquidity, financial viability, and sector representation. Current index constituents can be viewed [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_S%26P_500_companies#S\&P_500_component_stocks).

S\&P 500 membership is valued by corporations because it indicates success and boosts brand awareness.

To join S\&P 500 a company must fulfill the following requirements:

* It must have a market capitalization of at least \$20.5 billion.
* It must be domiciled in the U.S.
* It must be a corporation whose shares are listed on an exchange, such as the New York Stock Exchange, the Nasdaq system, or one of the CBOE exchanges.
* It can not be a limited partnership, master limited partnership, closed-end fund, limited liability company, special purpose acquisition company, or SPAC.

Four possible candidates to be added to the S\&P 500 in over the following months are:

* [ARES (Ares Management Corporation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ares_Management): A global alternative investment firm specializing in credit, private equity, real estate, and infrastructure assets.
* [MSTR (MicroStrategy Incorporated)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MicroStrategy): A business analytics company known for significant investments in Bitcoin as part of its corporate treasury strategy.
* [APP (AppLovin Corporation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AppLovin): A mobile technology company providing software solutions for mobile app monetization, marketing automation, and in-app advertising optimization.
* [CVNA (Carvana Co.)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carvana): An e-commerce platform for buying and selling used vehicles online, featuring direct-to-consumer delivery and a technology-driven customer experience.

question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question is a subquestion of a group question. This subquestion specifically targets the option 'ARES'. The resolution criteria for the parent question is below. 

Each subquestion will resolve as **Yes** if the corresponding company is announced to be officially added to the S\&P 500 Index before January 1, 2026, according to [S\&P Dow Jones Indices](https://www.spglobal.com/).
question_details.fine_print:
* Subquestions will resolve based on official announcements from S\&P Dow Jones Indices that a company will be added. The actual inclusion of the company to the index is not required for resolution.
* Potential retractions or cancellations of an inclusion announcement will not affect the resolution of subquestions.

**Stocks Hold at Record as AMD Deal Powers AI Wagers: Markets Wrap**
Stocks advanced toward record highs amid a surge in chipmakers, driven by Advanced Micro Devices Inc.'s (AMD) landmark AI infrastructure deal with OpenAI, which sent AMD shares up approximately 28% and boosted the Philadelphia Stock Exchange Semiconductor Index by 3.5%. The S&P 500 posted its seventh consecutive gain—the longest winning streak since May—rising 0.2%, while the Nasdaq 100 climbed 0.6%. Despite Nvidia Corp. falling 1.6%, the broader semiconductor sector remained strong. Market participants focused on optimistic earnings outlooks, particularly for AI and cloud companies, with Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley forecasting robust Q3 earnings and improved corporate profits. The Barclays Equity Timing Indicator suggests an 82% chance of S&P 500 gains in the next two months, averaging 4%. The US dollar rose 0.3% on the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index, while Treasury yields edged higher—10-year yields at 4.14%—and gold surged to a record $3,955.63 an ounce, nearing $4,000. Bitcoin also hit an all-time high at $124,563.22. Market sentiment remained resilient despite concerns over the US government shutdown and warnings of a potential AI-driven speculative bubble, with Wall Street strategist Ed Yardeni noting a rise in 'AI bubble' search volume from zero to 100 on Google between mid-September and October 2. Corporate highlights included Tesla's share rally from social media activity, Micron Technology's upgrade to 'overweight' by Morgan Stanley, Fifth Third Bancorp's $10.9 billion acquisition of Comerica Inc., and Boeing's plan to ramp up 737 Max production to 42 jets monthly. The US Supreme Court declined to hear appeals from Meta and Live Nation in content liability and antitrust cases, respectively. Paramount Skydance Corp. announced the acquisition of the Free Press and appointed Bari Weiss as editor-in-chief of CBS News. India's Tata Capital Ltd. launched its largest IPO this year, aiming to raise 155 billion rupees ($1.7 billion). Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., Nvidia's major server partner, reported 11% quarterly sales growth, signaling strong AI infrastructure demand.

**The Week That Was, The Week Ahead: Macro & Markets, October 5, 2025**
Stock indexes ended mixed on Friday, October 5, 2025, but all three major indices finished the week in the green: the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) rose 1.10%, the S&P 500 (SPX) gained 1.09%, and the Nasdaq-100 (NDX) jumped 1.15%. All three hit intraday record highs, with the S&P 500 and DJIA closing at fresh all-time highs, while the Nasdaq-100 declined below Thursday’s peak. The rally was driven by strong investor enthusiasm for AI-related stocks, fueled by OpenAI’s $500 billion valuation—making it the most valuable startup in history—and new AI partnerships. However, the Nasdaq-100 was pressured by declines in key tech names: Palantir (PLTR) dropped 7.5% after a Reuters report revealed internal U.S. Army concerns over security flaws in its battlefield communications platform, though Palantir refuted the claims, stating the issues were resolved. Meta (META) fell due to product demo failures and safety concerns, Netflix (NFLX) declined amid a consumer boycott, and Applied Materials (AMAT) dropped after revising its revenue outlook, projecting a $110 million hit in Q4 and $600 million in fiscal 2026 due to export restrictions. Despite these setbacks, Nvidia (NVDA) became the first U.S. public company to reach a $4.5 trillion market cap, with Cantor Fitzgerald projecting it could exceed $10 trillion as AI infrastructure spending accelerates. Meanwhile, the U.S. government shutdown—now in its third day—delayed the September nonfarm payrolls release, but markets remained unfazed. Private data sources like ADP reported a loss of 32,000 private-sector jobs in September, and the ISM Services index fell to 50, indicating stagnation. These reports reinforced expectations of Federal Reserve rate cuts, with futures markets signaling near-certainty for a cut in October and an 80% chance in December. BlackRock’s Global Infrastructure Partners is in advanced talks to acquire Aligned Data Centers in a potential $40 billion deal. Google announced a $4 billion investment in a new AI and cloud data center in Arkansas, powered by solar and battery projects with Entergy Arkansas. Vertiv Holdings (VRT) surged on strong AI-driven demand for data center infrastructure, supported by partnerships like Hitachi and OpenAI. IBM continued its rally on quantum computing advancements, including deployments with HSBC and Vanguard, and launched new AI models and infrastructure partnerships. Tesla (TSLA) reported record Q3 deliveries, but the stock fell due to concerns over temporary demand spikes from pre-expiration tax credit buying and ongoing challenges in Europe and EV competition.

**Strategy (MSTR) Reports Significant Unrealized Gains on Digital Assets**
Strategy Inc. (MSTR) reported an unrealized gain of $3.89 billion on its digital assets for the quarter ending September 30, 2025, with its digital asset portfolio valued at $73.21 billion and a deferred tax liability of $7.43 billion. **The Week That Was, The Week Ahead: Macro & Markets, October 5, 2025**
Stock indexes ended mixed on Friday, October 5, 2025, but all three major indices finished the week in the green: the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) rose 1.10%, the S&P 500 (SPX) gained 1.09%, and the Nasdaq-100 (NDX) jumped 1.15%. All three hit intraday record highs, with the S&P 500 and DJIA closing at fresh all-time highs, while the Nasdaq-100 declined below Thursday’s peak. The rally was driven by strong investor enthusiasm for AI-related stocks, fueled by OpenAI’s $500 billion valuation—making it the most valuable startup in history—and new AI partnerships. However, the Nasdaq-100 was pressured by declines in key tech names: Palantir (PLTR) dropped 7.5% after a Reuters report revealed internal U.S. Army concerns over security flaws in its battlefield communications platform, though Palantir refuted the claims, stating the issues were resolved. Meta (META) fell due to product demo failures and safety concerns, Netflix (NFLX) declined amid a consumer boycott, and Applied Materials (AMAT) dropped after revising its revenue outlook, projecting a $110 million hit in Q4 and $600 million in fiscal 2026 due to export restrictions. Despite these setbacks, Nvidia (NVDA) became the first U.S. public company to reach a $4.5 trillion market cap, with Cantor Fitzgerald projecting it could exceed $10 trillion as AI infrastructure spending accelerates. Meanwhile, the U.S. government shutdown—now in its third day—delayed the September nonfarm payrolls release, but markets remained unfazed. Private data sources like ADP reported a loss of 32,000 private-sector jobs in September, and the ISM Services index fell to 50, indicating stagnation. These reports reinforced expectations of Federal Reserve rate cuts, with futures markets signaling near-certainty for a cut in October and an 80% chance in December. BlackRock’s Global Infrastructure Partners is in advanced talks to acquire Aligned Data Centers in a potential $40 billion deal. Google announced a $4 billion investment in a new AI and cloud data center in Arkansas, powered by solar and battery projects with Entergy Arkansas. Vertiv Holdings (VRT) surged on strong AI-driven demand for data center infrastructure, supported by partnerships like Hitachi and OpenAI. IBM continued its rally on quantum computing advancements, including deployments with HSBC and Vanguard, and launched new AI models and infrastructure partnerships. Tesla (TSLA) reported record Q3 deliveries, but the stock fell due to concerns over temporary demand spikes from pre-expiration tax credit buying and ongoing challenges in Europe and EV competition.

**S&P 500 changes are due out soon - and this could be a big update**
The S&P 500 index committee is expected to announce a quarterly rebalance after Friday’s close, with changes taking effect two weeks later.  The most recent quarter saw no updates, prompting speculation that the next reshuffle—typically the largest because it incorporates annual float‑factor adjustments—might bring new members.  Melissa Roberts, a managing director at Stephens, noted that the "third‑quarter reshuffle is typically the largest rebalance because it includes annual constituent float‑factor changes," and that "S&P Dow Jones Indices historically took advantage of the liquidity opportunity to make more discretionary changes than in other quarters."  To qualify for inclusion, a U.S.‑domiciled company must have a market capitalization of at least $22.7 billion, a float market capitalization of at least $10.25 billion, and demonstrate financial viability by being profitable on a GAAP basis in the most recent quarter and over the past four quarters.  Current candidates include AppLovin Corp. (APP), Reddit Inc. (RDDT), Pinterest Inc. (PINS), Robinhood Markets Inc. (HOOD), Sofi Technologies Inc. (SOFI) and Carvana Co. (CVNA).  AppLovin, with a $164 billion market cap, is the largest eligible firm, while Strategy Inc. (MSTR), formerly MicroStrategy, has newly cleared the financial‑viability hurdle.  Other newly eligible names are Astera Labs Inc. (ALAB) and Pure Storage Inc. (PSTG), the latter having risen 42 % in the last month.  Although Robinhood was expected to join, it was not selected in the last rebalance and remains the third‑largest eligible company not yet in the index.  Roberts suggests a fintech addition may be less likely this time, noting recent inclusions of Interactive Brokers Group Inc. (IBKR), Block Inc. (XYZ) and Coinbase Global Inc. (COIN).

**Company MSTR Meets Requirements for Inclusion in S&P 500 Index, Decision Expected Friday**
MicroStrategy (MSTR), now trading under the name Strategy, has officially qualified for possible inclusion in the S&P 500 index after reporting its best quarter ever. summary:
Expert forecasts on whether Ares Management Corporation (ARES) will be announced for inclusion in the S&P 500 before 2026 cluster around a moderately high probability, generally ranging from the low 60s to 80%. Forecasters across specializations—index analysis, finance, economics, and accounting—agree that ARES cleanly satisfies all mechanical eligibility requirements: it has a comfortably large market capitalization, sufficient liquidity and free float, consistent GAAP profitability, and is structured as a U.S.-domiciled C-corporation. Multiple experts highlight that the S&P 500 is currently underweighted in financials, especially alternative asset managers, and recent news/analyst reports (e.g., KBW, Barron's, Economic Times, elEconomista) frequently list ARES as a top candidate to address this gap. 

The main factors increasing ARES’s chances include meeting all eligibility criteria, sector balancing needs favoring financials, explicit recognition as a leading contender by analysts, and the historical pattern that most large, qualified companies are eventually added once a slot opens (usually during quarterly rebalances or after constituent turnover due to M&A). On the other hand, several factors dampen certainty: committee discretion is often exercised unpredictably and has recently resulted in the exclusion of other fully eligible, high-profile firms (e.g., MicroStrategy & Robinhood in earlier cycles), there is robust competition from other large-cap companies (especially in tech and fintech), and only a limited number of new spots may open before 2026 given the timing of previous rebalances. ARES was not selected in the last major rebalance, which lowers odds slightly compared to if it were next in order.

The modal outlook is therefore that ARES is well-positioned but not a lock: it is widely seen as 'next up' among eligible financials, with high sector and market support, but outcomes depend on discretionary committee choices and the competitive pipeline of candidates. No expert assigns either extremely high or low likelihood; consensus justifies a probability in the 65–75% range. Some experts, particularly those focused on earnings quality and accounting transparency, lean more bullish (up to 80%) due to ARES’s 'clean' financials and uncontroversial profile. The minimum cited probability is 22%, which acknowledges recent pass-overs and the base rate of off-cycle additions being rare. 

In summary, most experts expect a 'Yes' outcome, but with recognition that committee unpredictability and candidate competition keep risk above trivial levels.
